bestBHT.bht: Choosing rather to suffer affliction with the people of God, this person made a deliberate and mature decision, weighing the temporary pleasures of the world against the eternal pleasures of religion. They willingly endured ill treatment, finding greater value in suffering with the people of God than in enjoying temporary pleasures of sin. This decision demonstrates a willingness to give up worldly prospects and embrace a life of self-denying piety, even in the face of persecution, poverty, and scorn.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Choosing" implies a deliberate resolution, not a hasty impulse. He was forty years old, a time when the judgment is matured.
If the world has "pleasure" (Greek, "enjoyment") to offer, it is but "for a season." If religion bring with it "affliction," it too is but for a season; whereas its "pleasures are for evermore.
He balanced the best of the world with the worst of religion, and decidedly chose the latter.
Albert Barnes: He left the court, not because he was driven away; not because there was nothing there to gratify ambition or to be a stimulus to avarice; and not on account of harsh treatment...but because he deliberately preferred to share the trials and sorrows of the friends of God.

Every one who becomes a friend of God and casts in his lot with his people, though he may anticipate that it will be attended with persecution, with poverty, and with scorn, prefers this to all the pleasures of a life of gaiety and sin, and to the most brilliant prospects of wealth and fame which this world can offer.

In view of all the 'pleasures' which sin can furnish, and in view of the most brilliant prospects which this world can hold out, religion enables man to pursue a different path. They who become the friends of God are willing to give up all those fair and glittering anticipations, and to submit to whatever trials may be incident to a life of self-denying piety.
Marvin Vincent: To have temporary enjoyment of sin.
The emphasis is first on temporary and then on sin.
Archibald T. Robertson: Rather having chosen" (second aorist middle of αιρεω, to take for oneself a position).
To treat ill with (associative instrumental case), only known example save one in the papyri (second century A.D.), though κακουχεω in Hebrews 11:37; Hebrews 13:3.
Literally, 'to have temporary pleasure of sin.' Απολαυσις is old word from απολαυω, to enjoy, in N.T. only here and 1 Timothy 6:17.
John Gill: Choosing rather to suffer affliction with the people of God.
But then those are a poor, and an afflicted people; affliction is with them.
And this was more eligible to him, than to enjoy the pleasures of sin for a season.

bhtAttempts.bht: Hebrews 11:25 speaks of a deliberate and mature decision made by someone who weighed the temporary pleasures and afflictions of the world against the eternal pleasures offered by religion. This person chose the latter, willingly enduring ill treatment and finding greater value in suffering with the people of God rather than enjoying temporary pleasures of sin. This demonstrates a willingness to give up worldly prospects and embrace a life of self-denying piety, even in the face of persecution, poverty, and scorn.

Choosing rather to suffer affliction with the people of God, this person made a deliberate and mature decision, weighing the temporary pleasures of the world against the eternal pleasures of religion. They willingly endured ill treatment, finding greater value in suffering with the people of God than in enjoying temporary pleasures of sin. This decision demonstrates a willingness to give up worldly prospects and embrace a life of self-denying piety, even in the face of persecution, poverty, and scorn.

Choosing rather to suffer affliction with the people of God, this person made a deliberate and mature decision. They balanced the best of the world with the worst of religion and consciously chose the latter. They recognized that although the world may offer temporary pleasure, it is fleeting, while the pleasures of religion are everlasting. Despite the associated afflictions, this person willingly embraced a life of self-denying piety, valuing the enduring joy found in fellowship with the people of God over the temporary pleasures of sin.

Choosing rather to suffer affliction with the people of God, this person decided deliberately and maturely. They understood that while the world may offer temporary enjoyment, religion's pleasures are eternal. Balancing the best of the world with the worst of religion, they definitively opted for the latter. Despite the ill treatment and the temporary pleasure of sin, this person willingly embraced a life of self-denying piety, treasuring the enduring joy found in fellowship with the people of God.

Choosing rather to suffer affliction with the people of God, this person made a deliberate and mature decision. They balanced the best of the world with the worst of religion and decidedly chose the latter. Recognizing the temporary nature of worldly pleasures and the everlasting nature of the pleasures found in religion, they willingly endured ill treatment and exchanged the temporary enjoyment of sin for the enduring joy of a life spent in fellowship with the people of God.
